2.title: Eliezer Yudkowsky
2.clickbait: Cofounder, with Nick Bostrom, of the field of value alignment theory.

42.title: Nearest unblocked strategy
42.clickbait: If you patch an agent's preference framework to avoid an undesirable solution, what can you expect to happen?

178.title: Arbital "tag" relationship
178.clickbait: Tags are a way to connect pages that share a common topic.

370.editSummary: reflecting the fact that we only have one type of mark now.
370.title: Arbital mark
370.clickbait: What is a mark on Arbital? When is it created? Why is it important?

597.title: Arbital page clickbait
597.clickbait: The text you are reading right now is clickbait.

17b.title: Arbital lens
17b.clickbait: A lens is a page that presents another page's content from a different angle.

1ln.editSummary: alias. note to self: come back and explain new requisites system.
1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1rt.title: Arbital path
1rt.clickbait: Arbital path is a linear sequence of pages tailored specifically to teach a given concept to a user.

2c.title: Advanced agent properties
2c.clickbait: How smart does a machine intelligence need to be, for its niceness to become an issue?  "Advanced" is a broad term to cover cognitive abilities such that we'd need to start considering AI alignment.

2l.title: Advanced safety
2l.clickbait: An agent is *really* safe when it has the capacity to do anything, but chooses to do what the programmer wants.

2mx.title: Open subproblems in aligning a Task-based AGI
2mx.clickbait: Open research problems, especially ones we can model today, in building an AGI that can "paint all cars pink" without turning its future light cone into pink-painted cars.

2qp.title: Conservative concept boundary
2qp.clickbait: Given N example burritos, draw a boundary around what is a 'burrito' that is relatively simple and allows as few positive instances as possible.  Helps make sure the next thing generated is a burrito.

2qq.title: Querying the AGI user
2qq.clickbait: Postulating that an advanced agent will check something with its user, probably comes with some standard issues and gotchas (e.g., prioritizing what to query, not manipulating the user, etc etc).

2rz.title: Task identification problem
2rz.clickbait: If you have a task-based AGI (Genie) then how do you pinpoint exactly what you want it to do (and not do)?

2s0.title: Look where I'm pointing, not at my finger
2s0.clickbait: When trying to communicate the concept "glove", getting the AGI to focus on "gloves" rather than "my user's decision to label something a glove" or "anything that depresses the glove-labeling button".
2s0.text:
Suppose we're trying to give a [6w Task AGI] the task, "Make there be a strawberry inside room X" (e.g., a human could fulfill this task by buying a strawberry and putting it inside the room).  As part of setting up this task, we might want to communicate the notion of "strawberry".

One way of communicating the concept of "strawberry" is through a training set of human-selected cases of things that are and aren't strawberries.  For the sake of making a distinction between causal roles, let's say that one human, User1, is selecting training cases of objects and putting them in front of the AI's webcam; and another human, User2, is also looking at the object and pushing a button when they see something that looks like a strawberry.  The [6h intention] is that pressing the button will label positive instances of the goal concept, in this case, intended to be strawberries.  During the use phase, the AI will be able to generate its own objects to put inside the room, possibly with further feedback from User2.  We want these objects to be instances of our [6h intended] goal concept, aka, actual strawberries.

We could draw an intuitive causal model for this situation as follows:

![strawberry diagram](http://www.gliffy.com/go/publish/image/10423843/L.png)

Suppose that during the use phase, the AI actually creates a realistic plastic strawberry, one that will fool User2 into pressing the button.  Or, similarly, suppose the AI creates a strawberry that sprouts tiny legs and runs over to the button and presses it directly.

Neither of these are the goal concept that we wanted the AI to learn, but any *test* of the hypothesis "Is this classified as a positive instance of the goal concept?" will return "Yes, the button was pressed for that sort of thing / this action leads to a positive instance of the goal concept being achieved."  (If you imagine some other User3 watching this and pressing an override button to tell the AI that this fake strawberry wasn't really a positive instance of the intended goal concept, imagine the AI modeling and then manipulating or bypassing User3, etcetera.)

[comment: move this to sensory identification section:  However, in a case like this, it's not like the actual physical glove is inside the AGI's memory.  Rather, we'd be, say, putting the glove in front of the AGI's webcam, and then (for the sake of simplified argument) pressing a button which is meant to label that thing as a "positive instance".  If we want our AGI to achieve particular states of the environment, we'll want it to reason about the causes of the image it sees on the webcam and identify a concept over those causes - have a goal over 'gloves' and not just 'images which look like gloves'.  In the latter case, it could just as well fulfill its goal by setting up a realistic monitor in front of its webcam and displaying a glove image.  So we want the AGI to [2rz identify its task] over the causes of its sensory data, not just pixel fields.]

We can see this as an offshoot of the problem of [ identifying causal goal concepts] in the first place (rather than having a purely sensory goal concept that's solely over the webcam and reward button).  Besides what a human considers to be the intuitive "strawberry" concept, there may be other causal concepts that also separate the training data well into positive and negative instances, such as "objects which come from strawberry farms", "objects which cause (my psychological model of) User2 to think that something is a strawberry", or "any chain of events leading up to the positive-instance button being pressed".

The "look where I'm pointing, not at my finger" problem is that the labels on the training data are actually produced by a complicated causal lattice, e.g., (strawberry farm) -> (strawberry) -> (User2 sees strawberry) -> (User2 classifies strawberry) -> (User2 presses 'positive instance' button).  What we want to point to is the "strawberry" part of the chain of causality, but the finger we use to point there is our psychological classification of the training cases and our hand pressing the positive-instance button.

Furthermore, in terms of what model *best* separates the training cases, concepts that are further downstream in the chain of causality would be expected to classify the training data at least as well and usually better.

Again, for the sake of argument, suppose that at one point User2 slips on a banana peel and their finger slips and accidentally classifies a scarf as a positive instance of "strawberry".  There's no good way of accounting for this in terms of strawberries, strawberry farms, or even User2's psychology.  The concept that maximizes predictive accuracy over the training cases is to reason that things are more likely to be positive instances of the goal concept when there's a banana peel on the control room floor.  Similarly, if some deceptively strawberry-shaped objects slip into the training cases, or are generated by the AI [2qq querying the user], the best boundary that separates 'button pressed' from 'button not pressed' instances will be about what makes a human believe that something is a strawberry, and not the strawberry's organic composition.

A concept that's 'about' layers of the causal lattice that are further downstream of the strawberry, like User2's psychology or mechanical force being applied to the button, will implicitly take into account the upstream layers of causality (to the extent that something being strawberry-shaped causes a human to press the button, it's implicitly part of the model of "things that end applying mechanical force to the 'positive-instance' button").  A concept that's about upstream layers of the causal lattice can't take into account events downstream.  So if you're looking for pure predictive accuracy, the best model of the goal concept - given sufficient AGI understanding of the world - will always be "whatever makes the positive-instance button be pressed".

This is a problem because, e.g., what we actually want is for there to be a strawberry inside room X, not for there to be an object that looks like a strawberry, for the User2's brain to be rewritten to think the object is a strawberry, or for the AGI to seize the control room and press the positive instance button.

There's several potential approaches to this problem.  E.g., [2qp conservatism] would tell the AGI to try to produce causal strawberries that were similar to previous causal instances labeled positively.  [4w Ambiguity identification] would focus on trying to get the AGI to ask us whether we meant 'things that make humans think they're strawberries' or 'strawberry' - though this channel would need to go through an explicit description of concepts to work; if the AGI has to ask by generating a training case rather than by abstractly describing a concept, a sufficiently intelligent AGI will automatically receive an answer saying that the deceptive object is a positive instance (they'll have presented the human with a query in the form of something that psychologically fools a human into labeling it a strawberry, and the human will have said, "Yes, that's a strawberry").

A very direct approach, however, would be to try to define a supervised learning algorithm that would have some notion of causality and causal modeling, and that could be instructed somehow to try learning a *simple* or *direct* relation between the inferred causal models of the "possible strawberry" instances, and the values of the "sensory button" node within the training cases, with this relation not being allowed to pass through the causal model of User2 or mechanical force being applied to the button.

![strawberry diagram](http://www.gliffy.com/go/publish/image/10424137/L.png)

This approach is what we've labeled the "look where I'm pointing, not at my finger" open problem.  It seems potentially susceptible to initial approach within modern machine learning algorithms.

[2l Advanced-safety] note: in the limit of [2c advanced intelligence], the *best possible* classifier of the relation between the training cases and the observed button values will always pass through User2 and anything else that might mechanically press the button, so we somehow need to be sure that the "Possible strawberry" causal node being identified is not allowed to include complex functional properties that would in effect copy the model of User2.  This could be, e.g., because we know how the epistemic pressures on the model operate, and they're guaranteed to put all inference about User2 into the User2 node rather than letting it slop over onto elaborate functional properties of the Possible Strawberry node.  Nonetheless, trying to 'forbid' the AI from using the most effective classifier for the relation between Possible Strawberry? and observed values of Button is the sort of thing that's potentially subject to a [42 Nearest Unblocked] problem, where the 'real' simplest relation re-emerges in the advanced phase after being suppressed during the training phase.

2v.title: AI alignment
2v.clickbait: The great civilizational problem of creating artificially intelligent computer systems such that running them is a good idea.

36y.title: Goal-concept identification
36y.clickbait: Figuring out how to say "strawberry" to an AI that you want to bring you strawberries (and not fake plastic strawberries, either).

3d.title: Arbital
3d.clickbait: Arbital is the place for crowdsourced, intuitive math explanations.

3hs.title: Author's guide to Arbital
3hs.clickbait: How to write intuitive, flexible content on Arbital.

3n.title: Arbital "parent" relationship
3n.clickbait: Parent-child relationship between pages implies a strong, inseparable connection.

4m.title: AI alignment open problem
4m.clickbait: Tag for open problems under AI alignment.

4w.title: Identifying ambiguous inductions
4w.clickbait: What do a "red strawberry", a "red apple", and a "red cherry" have in common that a "yellow carrot" doesn't?  Are they "red fruits" or "red objects"?

5c.title: Ontology identification problem
5c.clickbait: How do we link an agent's utility function to its model of the world, when we don't know what that model will look like?

6q.title: Context disaster
6q.clickbait: Some possible designs cause your AI to behave nicely while developing, and behave a lot less nicely when it's smarter.

6r.title: Methodology of foreseeable difficulties
6r.clickbait: Building a nice AI is likely to be hard enough, and contain enough gotchas that won't show up in the AI's early days, that we need to foresee problems coming in advance.

6w.title: Task-directed AGI
6w.clickbait: An advanced AI that's meant to pursue a series of limited-scope goals given it by the user.  In Bostrom's terminology, a Genie.
